timeline.bodyText: OK, but isn't this against 12 factor?  (Shouldn't config come from EnvVar's)?
timeline.author: lesv

replies.bodyText:
I'm not sure the Java runtime (easily) supports file uploads anyway - so that or properties in pom.xml are probably the way to go here.
(The other samples use config.json files, and I was copying what they did.)
replies.author: ace-n

replies.bodyText: Update: decided to use env vars here.
replies.author: ace-n

timeline.bodyText: Not sure what to recommend here - this has lots of stuff wrong.
timeline.author: lesv

replies.bodyText:
Would it be better if this [API response] was converted to JSON, and processed that way?
(Not sure how possible/easy that conversion is off the top of my head, but it may be easier to conceptualize/work with.)
That would also fix the toString() and List<Object> usage.
replies.author: ace-n

replies.bodyText: Yea - either to Json, or pass a map with a well defined set of values.  The key is if you are using Object and casting, then you really should check before you actually do the cast.  Java is a strongly typed language, if you skip that, you are missing the point. (note - I'm not saying this is a good thing, only what is Idiomatic)
replies.author: lesv

timeline.bodyText: List is rarely a good idea.
timeline.author: lesv

replies.bodyText: Refactored (to use JsonObject) per the comment below.
replies.author: ace-n

timeline.bodyText: Lots of .toString()'s are often a flag of bad design.  .toString() on an object isn't guaranteed to provide something presentable.
timeline.author: lesv

timeline.bodyText: You rarely need private, and List<Object> is rarely correct.
